comment_body.0:
Location: New York (Will be moving to northern Europe.)

Price range: ~$35k

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or used: New or Used

Type of vehicle: Sports Car

Must haves: Great sound, predictable/communicative handling, quick.

Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): Manual

Intended use: Weekend car, occasional daily

Vehicles you've already considered: Mustang Gt350, Camaro SS 1LE, Cayman, BMW e36 with a 2jz swap, Corvette C7, Miata, s2000, r32 gtr, ???

Is this your 1st vehicle: No

Do you need a Warranty: No

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Yes Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: Depends

Additional Notes: I will be potentially be moving to Northern Europe (Sweden) within the next 1.5 years. The rules say i must own a car for 6 months before bringing it into the country to avoid paying extra taxes, so I am exploring my options. I want it to be a car that I could take thousands of miles road trips, while also being a great backroad/weekend car. (With the occasional commute thrown in). I would like to own it for a long time. Obviously i don’t want to spend too much on fuel/repairs, but i can do most minor repairs, and some larger ones. Sound is very important to me (rb26, e9x m3, LFA, and Murci are examples of what i think good sounds are, to help with the subjectiveness). Any comments and suggestions to other cars would be helpful, thanks.
comment_body.1:
Location: Northern California

Price Range: Up to $30k USD

Buying Used

Looking for: Sports Car/Occasional Track Car

Must Have: RWD, Manual

Intended use: Second car, fun car, classic weekend car

Vehicles I Have Considered: BMW Z4M, Porsche Boxster/Cayman, other “go-to” fun cars

No need for warranty, can do minor work, lots of good shops nearby for major work

Additional Notes: I have a lead on a 100k+ mile Z4M, single owner, impeccably maintained. Price is very close to my upper limit before any haggling. I am 6’4” and need to fit. I plan on abiding by SMOG and CARB regulations, so the engine and power it has is what it will stay with. I also have a small garage I want the car to fit in (188in). All of these things are leading me to think the Z4M coupe is a good car for me. I plan on financing the car through a credit union, because current conditions make getting a great loan comfortably easy for me, keeping my money free, rather than buying outright. I included the other cars I’ve considered, but this is primarily asking about the Z4M coupe and any reasons this could be a bad idea.
comment_body.2:
Location: Seattle-ish, WA

Price range: $20k-$40k

Lease or Buy: buy

New or used: either

Type of vehicle: small, sporty 2-door car

Must haves:

  • FUN
  • rwd preferred but awd/fwd reluctantly accepted if the rest is great
  • decently quick
  • enough room for a (small) hockey bag and <5' stick

Desired transmission: manual (why is this so hard to find??)

Intended use: weekend and errands since I wfh, no kids and no giant shopping trips

Vehicles you've already considered:

  • Toyota 86
  • Nissan 370Z
  • Mazda Miata MX5 RF
  • Audi TT (used; repair costs on the Mini have put me off euro cars a bit tho)
  • Honda S2000 (used; still kicking myself for not getting one earlier)
  • Lotus Elise (used, obv; also a horrible idea in practicality)
  • Mazda RX8 (used; another horrible idea re practicality but fun as hell)

Is this your 1st vehicle: no

Do you need a Warranty: can take it or leave it

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: very very minor, current lease does not allow for working on cars in lot

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: no

Additional Notes:

  • convertibles are fine if they have a hardtop
  • I'd occasionally be driving on some rough roads
  • stiff/sport suspension is fine
  • the fun requirement is pretty high - past cars have included a Mini Cooper S, Civic Si, and an 80's Camaro so I'm a little spoiled in that regard
  • must have some way to connect an iPhone, either with an aftermarket deck, aux/usb cable, or bt
  • I'm barely over 5' so head/legroom isn't remotely a concern
  • would love to have non-boring colors available
comment_body.3:
Location: Denmark

Price range: <75,000 DKK (10,000€)

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or used: Used

Type of vehicle: Coupe, Sedan or Hatch

Must haves: Reliability

Desired transmission: Manual

Intended use: Daily driver and fun rides

Vehicles you've already considered: Mazda MX-5, Lexus IS200, Honda Prelude, Toyota Celica, Honda Civic, Honda Accord Type S, Ford Fiesta

Is this your 1st vehicle: No

Do you need a Warranty: No

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Yes

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: Yes, but would prefer not

Additional Notes: I need a daily driver as my previous car was stolen (RIP) and I need it for my job once quarantine is over. I don't need much practicality (dailied a motorcycle for 4 years), just want something reliable and fun, hence ~2000s Japanese cars.

The MX-5 is my current top pick, but I'll only get an ok example with my budget and I'm scared of rust (common here).

Apart from the older Japanese cars, I've considered a 1.0 SCTI Fiesta. I can get a 2014 with very low miles and then get it chipped to 145 hp. It's the most reasonable choice and it's fairly fast and fun, but it's not something I'd just take out on a weekend drive and that's something I really enjoy.

comment_body.13: I got about a 15K budget. Any fast cars I could get for that? In the USA. Also looking for stick shift.
comment_body.14:
Budget: $5000-$30000

Want: A manual transmission weekend car I won't get bored of for a long time, can occasionally be used at autocross events, maybe HPDE track events, and can fit a big driver (6'2" 210lbs). Light weight, responsive handling, and smallness preferred.

Preferences: 2 seats, RWD, removable targa top > Removable hardtop > Fixed roof > Soft top, no polarizing stigma associated with the car/brand

Dealbreakers: FWD, 4 doors, automatic transmission

What I'm considering (In order from favorite to least favorite)

  1. C5/C6 Corvette - Value seems unreal. Especially the C5Z and C6 LS3. Love the targa tops too. A little heavier than other cars I'm considering. The high power engine is hard to use responsibly on roads.

  2. Porsche 987 - Torn between whether I prefer the Cayman or the Boxter. Also not sure how well they fit tall drivers. Unsure about owning a Porsche as a guy in his 20s, I don't know if the car screams "rich douchebag" or if I'm just being overly dramatic.

  3. NC Miata - Love the price and performance. I'm very concerned about my ability to fit in one. I test drove one with stock seats and barely could get comfortable. I don't think it would ever pass the broomstick test even with buckets.

  4. Saturn Sky - Redline trim seems to be everything I want. Very limited aftermarket, no hard tops or roll bars, I don't know if the car fits tall people well.

  5. Honda S2000 - Seems to be a good alternative to the Miata, but just as cramped.

  6. Nissan 370Z - Haven't investigated this car much. Seems like it could be a good match for me.

GT86 - Between the boy racer stigma, unnecessary rear seats, and the cheap interior, I'm out.

Mustang, Camaro - Not open to consideration. I don't want a pony car to pair with my G8.

comment_body.17:
Bay Area California

Looking to spend max $6000

I’ve been torn between these three cars: WRX, E46/36, or an Acura TSX/TL

must be manual.

I know this is a weird mashup of cars but here’s my reasoning. I want a practical yet sporty car that can be had for my budget and these are the three that I’ve found. Reliability is a factor to an extent which is why I have my doubts about the first two, but I am capable of doing my own work on the car so if the WRX and BMW are fairly easy to work on I have no problem with that. I like the idea of the bimmer for the AWD aspect, the WRX for the sheer fun and practicality(I’m an outdoors kinda person) and the Acura for sheer reliability and cost effectiveness.

Location: PNW

Intended use: Daily driver

Vehicles you've already considered: MR2, LS400, SC400, Miata, e30 325i

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: I've done the timing chain on the 22r in my 89 Toyota Pickup as well as the front main seal and a lot of other smaller jobs. Some work on the Toyota 2uz engine including starter replacement. Also have helped friends with bigger jobs such as dropping the transmission to replace the clutch and a head gasket replacement.

Additional Notes: I'm a big fan of Japanese vehicles, particularly Toyota. I find myself getting bored whenever I'm behind the wheel of something front wheel drive, but I can drive for days without getting tired of it when I'm in something rear wheel drive. As far as price range goes, I have a 4wd Chevy S10 with a 4.3l and 5 speed manual that I have up for sale or trade (probably not going anytime soon lol) so I'd like to keep the value around the same.

comment_body.38:
• Location: Dallas,TX

  • Price range: 5k usd

  • Lease or Buy: Buy

  • New or used: Used

  • Type of vehicle: Something sporty.

  • Desired transmission: manual

  • Intended use: I Daily a Tacoma but I’m looking for something fun and sporty for the weekends, will also be using the vehicle for doordash, looking for something that needs love.

  • Is this your 1st vehicle: no

  • Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: (fluids, alternator, battery, brake pads etc) yes

  • Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: (engine and transmission, timing belt/chains, body work, suspension etc ) I can do paint, and suspension work. I would like to learn engine and body work

  • Audi b5 s4 My favorite car on the list, best looking imo, great interior, easy to modify, amazing exhaust note. But I would be looking at high mileage and I worry how much maintenance would cost.

  • E36 m3: 2nd favorite car on the list. I’m scared of how high the mileage on these cars would be but they do look great and I’ve heard they aren’t to expensive to maintain.

  • Mk4 gti: I have a soft spot for this generation of gti. But mileage would probably be high and I’m worried about repair cost and reliability, also in the market for r32s but not sure how much they go for.

  • Miata: Always the answer, probably the most reasonable car here, I’m worried about cupholder space because of doordash. Probably the cheapest car on here to maintain. Most smiles per dollar.

  • Honorable mentions Civic hatch, rsx, Porsche Boxster, wrx

Location: Houston, TX

Price Range: Probably a max around 20k, possibly more or less depending on how long the pandemic lasts. Prefer closer to 15k if possible.

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or Used: Either, probably going to be lightly used for what I want

Type of Vehicle: Sedan or Coupe if the price is right, prefer a Sedan though. Maybe a small hatchback.

Must haves: Fuel Efficient, Looks Nice, Good sound system, Fun to Drive

Nice to Have: Dark gray color, I'd be cool with anything other than silver if the price was right

Desired Transmission: Auto, will go manual if it's a decent bit cheaper

Intended Use: Daily Driver

Vehicles you've already considered: Honda Civic (2016 or Newer, currently my first option), 2021 Hyundai Elantra (probably will be out of my price range)

Budget: i would say $400 a month.

New or used: probably new unless it is lexus

Type of vehicle: I want something safe and with good mileage and also comfort. This would be my second car. My current is an older. Luxury car and I enjoy the comfort but it guzzles gas like

Must haves: all the newer safety features. Can be older if it has collision assist, autowipers, comfortable seats

Intended use: daily driver

Dersired transmission: Automatic

Vehicles considered/considering: 2019 genesis g70, lexus

Is 1st vehicle?: No

Do you need a warranty: yes unless i can be convinced otherwise in a specific case

Can you do minor work on your own vehicle: beyond changing the filter no. Could probably do oil if I really tried

Major work?: I absolutely cannot

Additional tips: The winters get very cold and weather conditions can be quite poor. I do a good mix of city and highway driving leaning more towards city driving. My current car like I said I love the features even for how old it is (heated/ac seats, backup sensor, etc) but it needs gas every other trip and is about to hit 150k. I would love something luxurious but reliable and comfortable with decent mpg
comment_body.43: Looking at buying a 99 Honda passport (rebadged isuzu rodeo) with only 60k miles as a new daily. Looks to be in great condition and rarely used. Apart from checking for rust, is there anything important I should check out before buying? Any other thoughts/experience with this vehicle I should know? Concerns with a 20 year old car?
comment_body.44:
Interested in other people's thoughts on the Subaru Ascent vs the Honda Pilot.

I'm considering getting out of my 2010 Venza V6 and into one of these vehicles. I have two large dogs and a pregnant wife (early stages though), and I want a safe and spacious vehicle with AWD. I'm thinking about a lease because of the times (would rather put money in the stock market as much as we can and I might want a hybrid in a few years).

I'm in Canada by the way, and looking at lowest leather trims. The Pilot EX-L I can likely get for about $550 a month for 3 years, because I am related to a sales manager and can get invoice price. This would also be no stress buying. The Ascent Limited could be $600-$700 depending on how much I can negotiate off MSRP (Subaru don't usually offer good deals here). 20,000km/year.

I think my wife would like the Ascent a bit more because it feels smaller to drive to my understanding, and is a couple inches smaller. The interior is nicer in some ways, though not necessarily functionally better. Ascent looks more awkward to me on the outside. Ascent has more ground clearance but Honda the superior AWD torque vectoring.

I'm also open to other options. I do really like the Telluride but the lease rates suck and it's more expensive.

Our other car will be a Honda Clarity Touring which I expect to pick up this coming week. Thanks!
comment_body.45: There's a $9000 Mazdaspeed 6 with less than 60,000 miles on it for sale near me. I have no desire to buy it currently, but damn I'll be wishing I had that once November rolls around.
comment_body.46: Is there such thing as a reliable, RWD manual, luxury car? I think lexus ticks all the boxes but manual is impossible to find on the used market and pricey for what you get.

Location: Southern United States

Price range: 50k-100k

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or used: New or recent model used

Type of vehicle: Coupe or sedan

Must haves:

Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): Automatic

Intended use: Weekend car

Is this your 1st vehicle: No

Do you need a Warranty: No, but preferred

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No

Additional Notes: 2020 Corvette is the current front runner. Pretty fast and exotic looking, for under 60k MSRP. Although my dad thinks that everyone and their brother will have them once they start becoming more available and they will lose some of their 'wow factor' once you start seeing them all the time. They like the idea of a Tesla but don't like that it doesn't look very sporty or exotic (this is one of my main gripes with Tesla, but the people in charge know better than me).

extra : My mom likes the idea of a Mercedes. Does anyone have anything to say about the modern reliability of a Mercedes? We used to own a e39 bmw and kind of swore off luxury European cars after paying so much for maintenance and repair.
comment_body.51:
Location: Kentucky, USA

Price Range: $0-30,000

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or Used: Used

Type of vehicle: Sports sedan, coupe, or wagon

Must Haves: Power and handling first. AWD or RWD preferable

Transmission: Manual preferable

First Vehicle?: No

A second option would be to keep the G and just buy a cheaper daily driver (but i still want it to be fun such as a Miata, but those are too small) while I just build out my G35. The build might ultimately be a waste of time though because the handling is absolutely horrible (of course maybe a fine tuned suspension might give it better handling, but it might be a very expensive risk)

comment_body.57:
Location: Southern New Hampshire

Price range: $20,000 or under

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or used: Used

Type of vehicle: Sportscar

Must haves: AWD but would consider non-AWD cars

Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): Manual or auto, but would prefer manual

Intended use: Daily driver & delivery vehicle

Vehicles you've already considered: WRX, Miata, 350z, Camry, e90 & e92 335i, and probably a few others

Is this your 1st vehicle: No

Do you need a Warranty: No

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: No, but willing to learn

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No

Additional Notes: Alright, I'm having a "midlife" crisis and I want something faster than what I've had so far. Currently I'm driving a 2015 Subaru Impreza wagon. It was everything I didn't want in a car except for the AWD. Currently I'm working as a delivery driver and I make pretty decent money, thankfully I'm considered essential so I can keep working. I understand getting a premium car like a 335i for deliveries is a bad idea so I'm not too invested in that due to maintenance costs. The Camry is my economical choice but I just feel like it won't be aggressive enough for what I want. The 350z has the style I want, but I'm worried about driving it year round in New England. Miata is always the answer so I've definitely considered one of these and just throwing a turbo in it for good times, smiles per gallon and all that. Lastly, and seems to be the winner so far is a 2015+ WRX. I don't want a WRX with an EJ motor due to all of the ringland issues they have and all of the other problems. Although I love the rumble and body style I just know I drive way too much and it would only be a matter of time before the engine blew up on me. I'm open to other options, these are just what I've considered so far.

EDIT: I've also considered just getting a motorcycle to enjoy myself when I'm not working but then I wouldn't be able to ride for at least half of the year or more. I'm in a real conundrum.

TYIA

Additional Notes: Even though I could be anywhere in the US at anytime, my home is in colorado and will be spending time there from time to time. I really need the car to be good in the snow (hence the AWD necessity). I also want the car to be a comfort to drive for 8-10 hours at a time and can lay down some power if I want to do a few pulls. Thanks for any answers!
